item.title: NATO has rejected Ukraine’s demand for no-fly zones. What sounds like a humanitarian measure is also an act of war. We explain why https://t.co/RTEiXHbWz5
Defence spending will now rise more rapidly and that 2% of GDP will become a de facto minimum across NATO, reckons Citigroup https://t.co/RZNLnuSSw2

“There's nothing special about me. The only thing that’s different in my story is that my father did not stop me.”
To mark #IWD2022, @Malala and @zannymb discuss how to improve the lives of girls everywhere.
Subscribers can sign up to watch here: https://t.co/Cg6G1x8syd https://t.co/Uzv8spLrau

The war has started consolidating Europe’s belief in itself and its ideals, and may increase its willingness to fight for them https://t.co/WLPabFuA13

Volodymyr Zelensky’s charisma and acting background have suited him perfectly to a war immersed in social media https://t.co/sCv2kRXa0R

What is happening in Ukraine? We explain in maps by illustrating Russian advances, the build-up of troops and opposition to the war https://t.co/mylLphFFIF
Russia’s attack on Zaporizhzhia, a nuclear plant in Ukraine, is unprecedented. Operational nuclear reactors have never been in the firing line like this https://t.co/shH928C1ws

Tweets from Ukraine’s defence ministry tell citizens which parts of a tank are most vulnerable to Molotov cocktails. Ordinary people risk their lives by standing in front of armoured vehicles https://t.co/VRjSdsePeg
Ukraine’s offence was to be an independent country. Lithuania’s was to give Taiwan an opportunity to hint that it is https://t.co/MvVhDY8Z34

♦️ Russian forces take control of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant.
♦️ Volodymyr Zelensky says that meeting Vladimir Putin is “the only way to stop this war”.
♦️ Foreign ministers meet to discuss the war, including requests for NATO to impose a no-fly zone.
Catch up👇

“He’s gone from coercion...to now punishment. I think he thinks, at this point, if he can’t get Ukraine, he’s pretty much going to destroy it.” Foreign-affairs specialist Fiona Hill assesses Vladimir Putin’s motivations in Ukraine, on “The Economist Asks” https://t.co/3d3tEnLD1i https://t.co/NOA2lAE8Tq
The sight of Russia’s central bank being hit so hard by sanctions no one expected will lead China to increase its efforts to establish the yuan as a reserve currency https://t.co/Q2fWuj8a9w

What might Vladimir Putin do next, and how should NATO respond? @shashj, The Economist’s defence editor, gives his take.
Read our latest analysis: https://t.co/Ku48sueqh2 https://t.co/iXnyxSY6O5
He insists that the world back off while he sharpens his knife and sets about his slaughter. Other countries must stand up to him https://t.co/T4OA37kxtU

Many fear that Kyiv could share the fate of Grozny, the capital of Chechnya, much of which was left in ruins after an artillery pounding in 1994 killed 20,000 civilians.
It is a memory which should frighten the Russians, too https://t.co/qTiqWcRUSF"
The UN’s refugee agency reckons up to 4m people—almost a tenth of Ukraine’s population—might flee in the coming weeks https://t.co/YLGtacqqdJ
Germany has announced it would spend an extra €100bn ($111bn) on defence in 2022, tripling its defence budget for the year https://t.co/BF5TfR9FbC
Ukraine’s largest paediatric unit is reeling from the Russian invasion. Yet to a surprising extent it is still working, as these photos show https://t.co/kmTdMIX5z2

Ukrainians are trusting strangers as they never have before. Armies of civilian volunteers are importing military kit from other parts of Europe and helping to organise evacuations https://t.co/UvzjWRxSEZ
China wants a sphere of influence in Asia in which its writ goes unchallenged by America. As a result, it has made its peace with Russian imperialism https://t.co/yQS20YY64K
Not all of those leaving are Ukrainians, and some non-white refugees are receiving a hostile welcome https://t.co/33M1SDxi8T
So far, China has said it will continue trading with Russia as normal. However, access to the yuan may be of little use to Russia’s faltering economy https://t.co/h2NEE6QTov
"Vladimir Putin’s propaganda machine cannot explain away all of this with ravings about neo-Nazis and NATO threats to Mother Russia" https://t.co/luYesHCxlU
To Taiwanese people, the parallels between what Vladimir Putin is doing to Ukraine and what Xi Jinping might do to Taiwan are glaring https://t.co/J5NACOF6xV
Despite Vladimir Putin’s railing against the West’s “empire of lies”, plenty in Russia see his war for what it is: a conflict entirely of his own making https://t.co/wvng6fczQh
Ukrainian air defences have been persistent, but the Russians were also poorly prepared for the amount of resistence they have encountered https://t.co/9wDw6Xh5hq

Most Russians had no idea that their country was going to war until just before it did so, in part because the idea made no sense, in part because they were lied to https://t.co/gl1xzMLqj8

The Ukrainian people have discovered they are ready to die for the idea that they should choose their own destiny. To a cynical dictator that must be incomprehensible. To the rest of humanity it is an inspiration https://t.co/OpbBDyphDD
The military build-up around Ukraine is the biggest concentration of firepower in Europe since the cold war https://t.co/mHFjOkwomI

From the start, Vladimir Putin has made clear that this is a war of escalation. He threatens to be more destructive even if that means resorting to a nuclear weapon. The world must stand up to him. Our cover this week https://t.co/RuaETMqc9z https://t.co/2uzypdsMy2
